caption_text: It formed layers on the contact material, both externally and on the sur- faces of some vesicles within contact coke lumps (Fig. 2). At contact temperatures of 500°C the PC layers on coke were not more than a few microns thick, while at 1000°C layers were up to 100 p. and occasionally of even greater thickness (Fig. 3).
raw_window: It formed layers on the contact material, both externally and on the sur- faces of some vesicles within contact coke lumps (Fig. 2).
At contact temperatures of 500°C the PC layers on coke were not more than a few microns thick, while at 1000°C layers were up to 100 p.
and occasionally of even greater thickness (Fig. 3).

caption_text: The typical form of PC deposits was that of layers which are continuous on a surface but varied in thickness with the conical structure of the deposit (Fig. 3). Some sections through larger cones within the thicker PC deposits, especially those formed at comparatively high temperatures, contained dis- continuous circumferential cracks (Fig. 3), fairly regularly spaced. These apparently had formed partly by anisotropic shrinkage of PC during 'annealing' after deposition and partly by aniso- tropic shrinkage of PC during cooling from its temperature of formation to ambient.
raw_window: The typical form of PC deposits was that of layers which are continuous on a surface but varied in thickness with the conical structure of the deposit (Fig. 3).

Some sections through larger cones within the thicker PC deposits, especially those formed at comparatively high temperatures, contained dis- continuous circumferential cracks (Fig. 3), fairly regularly spaced.

These apparently had formed partly by anisotropic shrinkage of PC during 'annealing' after deposition and partly by aniso- tropic shrinkage of PC during cooling from its temperature of formation to ambient.

caption_text: CARBONS OBTAINED BY THERMAL AND CATALYTIC CRACKING OF COAL TARS 195 that of aggregates of spheres varying from micron size to 10-20 /i in diameter (Fig. 4) ; above 10-20 p. they coalesced to form 'welded' aggregates (Fig. 5). The spheres are strongly optically anisotropic and have a concentric structure as indicated by the sense in which plane-polarized light is absorbed, and by the stationary extinction cross observed with crossed niçois when the microscope stage is rotated (Fig. 5, lower half).
raw_window: CARBONS OBTAINED BY THERMAL AND CATALYTIC CRACKING OF COAL TARS 195 that of aggregates of spheres varying from micron size to 10-20 /i in diameter (Fig. 4) ; above 10-20 p.
they coalesced to form 'welded' aggregates (Fig. 5).

The spheres are strongly optically anisotropic and have a concentric structure as indicated by the sense in which plane-polarized light is absorbed, and by the stationary extinction cross observed with crossed niçois when the microscope stage is rotated (Fig. 5, lower half).

caption_text: Some SPC spheres and aggregates were deposited on PC and later enclosed by further deposits of PC (Fig. 6). It seems possible that the concentric structure of PC may be initiated by SPC spheres deposited on the growing PC surface. The spheres of SPC are usually too small for measurement of reflectance but their optical properties appear to be closely similar to those of PC in the same sample.
raw_window: Some SPC spheres and aggregates were deposited on PC and later enclosed by further deposits of PC (Fig. 6).
It seems possible that the concentric structure of PC may be initiated by SPC spheres deposited on the growing PC surface.
The spheres of SPC are usually too small for measurement of reflectance but their optical properties appear to be closely similar to those of PC in the same sample.

caption_text: There were also transitions between the two types of sphere, where the core (a few microns across) was isotropic, with a transition to an outer rim which was as strongly anisotropic as normal SPC (Fig. 5). The fact that no transitions were observed in the reverse sense suggested that once a circumferen- tial pattern had been established this persisted. The reflectance of such isotropic material was higher than that of typical carbon black and similar to that of SPC.
raw_window: There were also transitions between the two types of sphere, where the core (a few microns across) was isotropic, with a transition to an outer rim which was as strongly anisotropic as normal SPC (Fig. 5).
The fact that no transitions were observed in the reverse sense suggested that once a circumferen- tial pattern had been established this persisted.
The reflectance of such isotropic material was higher than that of typical carbon black and similar to that of SPC.

caption_text: Evidently after deposition it shrank to form cracks, some of which were later infilled with PC (Fig. 7). The 1C was of low reflectance by comparison with PC in the sample. Not all the material under this heading was carbon black—for example, part of the material formed during the cracking of fluidized-bed tar.
raw_window: Evidently after deposition it shrank to form cracks, some of which were later infilled with PC (Fig. 7).
The 1C was of low reflectance by comparison with PC in the sample.
Not all the material under this heading was carbon black—for example, part of the material formed during the cracking of fluidized-bed tar.

caption_text: It had a well- defined mosaic structure, much coarser than that of the coke used as contact material (Fig. 8). Occasional sub-spherical grains of PtC having radial structure were presumably formed by rapid carbonization of individual droplets of residual pitch (Fig. 9). When the feed material was fluidized-bed tar, PtC was absent or rare and in its place there occurred irregular masses of isotropic carbon.
raw_window: It had a well- defined mosaic structure, much coarser than that of the coke used as contact material (Fig. 8).
Occasional sub-spherical grains of PtC having radial structure were presumably formed by rapid carbonization of individual droplets of residual pitch (Fig. 9).
When the feed material was fluidized-bed tar, PtC was absent or rare and in its place there occurred irregular masses of isotropic carbon.

caption_text: A 900°C coke (see Table 1) prepared from a low-ash Stockton No. 2 Block (New Zealand) coal was chosen as contact material for most runs because it contained only small amounts of inorganic material which might be expected to have some catalytic influence. Table 2 gives the ash analysis of the coal from which this coke had been prepared.

caption_text: 4,7 Temperature of cracking The main effect of raising the temperature of cracking from 500 to 1000°C was to increase sharply the total yield of carbon (from 3-10 per cent at 500°C to over 60 per cent at 1000°C) (Table 3).
raw_window: 4,7 Temperature of cracking The main effect of raising the temperature of cracking from 500 to 1000°C was to increase sharply the total yield of carbon (from 3-10 per cent at 500°C to over 60 per cent at 1000°C) (Table 3).
The relative distribution of various types of carbon was also markedly affected by the temperature of cracking.
At increasing tempera- tures PC and especially SPC became more abun- dant while 1C and PtC became rare or were totally absent from the samples.
table_reason: Only S0 mentions the table and provides a standalone caption-like description.

caption_text: -1.2 Contact time of cracking A comparison of results obtained: for carbons at the same temperature but at different contact times (Table 3) showed that at low temperatures (between 500 and 700°C) only the formation of PtC was significantly affected by the contact time of cracking, in that more pitch coke was obtained at long contact times.
raw_window: -1.2 Contact time of cracking A comparison of results obtained: for carbons at the same temperature but at different contact times (Table 3) showed that at low temperatures (between 500 and 700°C) only the formation of PtC was significantly affected by the contact time of cracking, in that more pitch coke was obtained at long contact times.
At high temperatures (between 800 and 1000°C), variation of the contact time of cracking did not appear to influence the relative distribution of carbon types.
These find- ings may augment the observation that total carbon formation was most dependent on contact time at 196 ' 8 .
table_reason: Only S0 mentions "Table" and contains the caption-like description.

caption_text: 4.3 Tar composition The composition of carbon samples obtained from two typical tars—a gasworks vertical-retort tar and a low-temperature fluidized-bed tar—at relatively long contact times in the temperature range 500-1000°C are summarized in Table 4.
raw_window: 4.3 Tar composition The composition of carbon samples obtained from two typical tars—a gasworks vertical-retort tar and a low-temperature fluidized-bed tar—at relatively long contact times in the temperature range 500-1000°C are summarized in Table 4.
Carbon yields were generally lower from the fluidized-bed tar, as would be expected from its more aliphatic composition.
Much the same pattern of variation in the rela- tive abundance of carbon types in the solid pro- ducts of cracking was observed with the two different tars.
table_reason: The sentences describe experimental results and analysis, not a caption summarizing table content.

caption_text: 4.4 Catalysts The addition of iron and zinc catalysts to the contact material used in some runs promoted the formation of 1C, especially at 900-1000°C (Table 5).
raw_window: 4.4 Catalysts The addition of iron and zinc catalysts to the contact material used in some runs promoted the formation of 1C, especially at 900-1000°C (Table 5).
Some fragments of metal were wholly sur- rounded by thick layers of 1C.
When iron alone was used as the contact material (without coke) similar effects were observed.
table_reason: The sentences describe experimental observations and results, not a caption summarizing table content.

caption_text: 4.5 Steam addition As indicated in Table 6, when 8-32 per cent of steam was added to the vertical-retort tar prior to cracking the total yield of carbon generally increased (except at 32 per cent steam addition at 1000°C, where the water-gas reaction became intensive).
raw_window: 4.5 Steam addition As indicated in Table 6, when 8-32 per cent of steam was added to the vertical-retort tar prior to cracking the total yield of carbon generally increased (except at 32 per cent steam addition at 1000°C, where the water-gas reaction became intensive).
1C and PtC became more abundant in the carbon products obtained at low (500-700°C) temperatures.
SPC was absent in these samples.
table_reason: The sentences describe experimental results and observations, not a caption summarizing table content.

caption_text: 4.6 Oxygen addition The effect of adding 1-12 per cent oxygen to the vertical-retort tar was to raise the yield of carbon, TABLE 5.
